Problem:
Consider a controlled system which is governed by the differential equation \\(\\dot{x} = Dx\\) where D is a linear operator. An external control is modeled by multipling the state vector \\(x(t)\\) by a matrix exponential \\( e^{Mt} \), where M is a time-independent matrix and t is the time variable.

If another intervention \\(e^{Nt}x(t)\\) (where N is a constant matrix) is applied at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), will the endpoint state \\(x(T)\\) for T > t_1 depend only on D and not on M or N?
Explanation: The endpoint \\(x(T)\\) will depend on all three matrices D, M, and N. The new intervention with \\(e^{Nt} \\) further diverges the system’s evolution path from what it would be under the effect of D alone, reflecting the combined influences of these transformations.
